abstracts.cdata!:
The Rural Finance Project for Vietnam
            had a satisfactory outcome, a moderate institutional impact,
            and a moderate risk to development outcome.  Both the Bank
            and the borrower performances were satisfactory.  Findings
            of the project include:  A study is needed to better
            understand all the implicit subsidies throughout the system.
            The Bank also needs to consider a more proactive approach to
            closed projects with loan funds that are being relent within
            the same fund, particularly with respect to loan size caps.
            Both the Bank and the borrower were very slow to resolve the
            Vietnam Bank for the Poor (VBP) involvement issue and could
            also have made better analytical use of available data on
            costs per job created.  The three main lessons learned from
            the project are: A) Training programs should be designed
            with the objective of not only making delivery more
            efficient but of creating a national capacity in financial
            services. B) The Bank needs to revisit the impact of
            conditionality on project implementation through the life of
            the credit not simply the life of the project and to design
            conditionality to adapt to change. C) The Bank should
            establish achievable participating financial institution
            (PFI) participation criteria at appraisal and ensure that at
            least a significant number of PFIs can meet them prior to appraisal.

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Rural Finance Project
            for Vietnam was satisfactory, the sustainability was highly
            likely, the institutional development impact was
            substantial, and the Bank and Borrower performance were both
            satisfactory. The lessons learned indicate that the criteria
            of the participating financial institutions need to be
            periodically reviewed and adjusted to market conditions.
            More attention should be given to diversification of the
            Rural Development Fund (RDF) lending. The institutional
            development plan targets should be reviewed and updated more
            often to reflect better the new challenges and issues.
            Direct credit by crop or type of investments, at subsidized
            interest rates have not sustained economic growth. Poor
            financial conditions within participating financial
            institutions have severely constrained the projects'
            sustainability. Private financial resource mobilization is
            extremely important for the institutional sustainability.
            When interest rates either fall significantly below, or move
            well above prevailing market rates, serious implementation
            problems emerge - above market-rates have resulted in slow
            disbursements, and below-market rates have led to
            concentration of credit to relatively wealthy clients.

repnme.cdata!: Extending credit to the rural poor of Vietnam

abstracts.cdata!:
Between 1998 and 2001, a World
            Bank-assisted Rural Finance project provided nearly $650,000
            to 250,000 rural Vietnam households. Almost a third of the
            borrowers were women. The loans, averaging $360 each and
            provided through seven participating banks, were used to
            expand farm production, agricultural processing, and
            trading. Without the project, most of these borrowers would
            have reportedly turned to money lenders, whose costs are
            much higher. The total credit provided by the Bank for this
            project was $110 million. The project has supported several
            financing initiatives, one of them being mobile banking,
            which provides services to remote areas without bank
            branches. Already, the benefits of mobile banking exceed the
            costs, highlighting the need to provide more and better
            banking services to people in remote areas who until now
            have had no formal banks to serve them.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Rural Finance Project supports
            several key components of the IDA's country assistance
            strategy, which are: 1) assist transition to a market
            economy; 2) strengthen the rural finance system through
            finance targeted to agriculture and small and medium
            enterprises in rural areas, accompanied by technical
            assistance; and 3) reduction of poverty through promoting
            growth and enabling the poor to respond to opportunities to
            improve their welfare. The project will also assist Viet Nam
            in its efforts to improve living conditions in the rural
            areas through: 1) encouraging private sector investments; 2)
            strengthening the banking system's capacity to finance
            private sector investments; and 3) increasing access of the
            rural poor to financial services. The project will consist
            of the following components: 1) rural development fund; 2)
            fund for the rural poor; 3) equipment; 4) vehicles; 5)
            training; and 6) technical assistance.
